title: Example: Grid World

definitions.Maze-like problem: The agent lives in a grid. Walls block the agent's path.
definitions.Noisy movement: Actions do not always go as planned. 80% of the time, the action North takes the agent North (if there is no wall there). 10% of the time, North takes the agent West; 10% East. If there is a wall in the direction the agent would have been taken, the agent stays put.
definitions.The agent receives rewards each time ste: Small 'living' reward each step (can be negative). Big rewards come at the end (good or bad).

summary: The slide presents an example of a maze-like problem in a grid world where an agent navigates through a grid. The agent receives small 'living' rewards each step and aims to maximize the sum of rewards. The agent's movement is noisy, with a 80% chance of moving North if there is no wall, and a 10% chance of moving West or East. The agent receives big rewards at the end, which can be good or bad.
